title.narrative: Grid-Connected Rooftop PV Systems in Seychelles

description.narrative: Seychelles - Grid-Connected Rooftop PhotoVoltaic Systems

title.narrative: Grid-Connected Rooftop Photovoltaic Systems in Seychelles
Terminal Evaluation for Grid Connected roof Top PV In Seychelles
Project Completion Report for PV Project

description.narrative: Grid-Connected Rooftop Photovoltaic Systems:
independent political entity

- Finalize the Energy Act - Create an enabling environment for the uptake of PV systems in Domestic and Industrial use through legal regulatory and financial mechanisms - Significantly increase the number of grid connected PV systems by supporting the PUC to enable users to move to RETs.

comment.narrative:
All baselines for Renewable Energy Technology in Seychelles are non-existent or are set at 0 levels. The project will seek to
- reduced CO2 emissions from the power sector - install capacity of grid-connected PV systems (kWp) - increase electricity generation from installed grid-connected PV systems (kWh)

- Establishment of Independent Electricity Regulator - Education Awareness Campaign: implementing work plan finalized - Education Awareness Campaign: Audio and visual costs attributed to latter part above. - Capacity Needs Assessment: Conduct 4 additional workshops locally - Training on Financial Issues: SEC Staff economist to undergo training on RET financing

-Review of existing laws to establish Independent Electricity Regulator started -Education Awareness Campaign ongoing and will continue in 2016. production of Audio and visuals ongoing -Contract signed for Capacity Needs Assessment and 2 workshops held locally -Training on Financial Issues not started and postponed to 2016

-Complete Education and Awareness Campaign and Documentary for La Digue School - PV School project by installing PV systems on 2 schools on Praslin and La Digue - Conduct SIT Training Course and purchase equipment/tools for SIT - Purchase of PV monitoring toolkit to for National Performance Assessment - Prepare Project Completion Report - Conduct Terminal Evaluation

Education and Awareness Campaign and Documentary for La Digue School completed. 4 kilowatt installed on La Digue and 4 on Baie Ste Anne School. - Training completed with Seychelles Institute of Technology for energy installers. Training of Trainer completed. - Purchase of PV monitoring toolkit to for National Performance Assessment completed. Prepare Project Completion Report finalized t Terminal Evaluation completed and management response prepared and uploaded on ERC and PIMS

description.narrative: Increase the use of gridconnected photovoltaic PV systems as a sustainable means of generating electricity in selected main islands and smaller islands of the Seychelles
Amount of reduced CO2 emissions from the power sector compared to the project baseline by EOP tonnes CO2eq

comment.narrative:
Target 804 Achieved
It is estimated that emissions reduction of 9772 tonnes CO2eq has been achieved as of 15 July 2015 According to the Seychelles Energy Commission the amount of CO2 displaced by 1 unit 1 kWh of electricity generated from PV is approximately 700 grams The installed capacity for PV was 92 achieved in midJuly and projected to be close to 100 achieved by end of July The CO2 emissions reduction given as of midJuly is indicative of the weighted time period over which said capacity has been installed

description.narrative: Cumulative installed capacity of gridconnected PV systems kWp

comment.narrative:
Target 92 Achieved
Installed grid capacity from PV as of midJuly 2015 is 12428 kWp

description.narrative: Cumulative total electricity generation from installed gridconnected PV systems kWh

comment.narrative:
Target 822 achieved
Total electricity generation from PV systems had reached 13960297 kWh by midJuly 2015 This is based on the installed capacity and average specific yield of the PV systems

description.narrative: Comprehensive and strengthened policy and legal frameworks adopted to promote RETs and enable gridconnected renewable energy production
No of gridconnected RE production projects approved and facilitated by the IER by EOP

comment.narrative: At least 30

100 achieved and surpassed There are currently 163 installations installed July 2015
The systems installed are mostly between 37 kWp with most systems being installed in the domestic sector As noted in the last reporting period block shaving has been and continues to be the governing mechanism for determining system sizes in the domestic sector The commercial sector is responsible for the larger but fewer installations This is related to overall energy consumption as block shaving is irrelevant to the commercial tariff

description.narrative: No of gridconnected RE production projects that benefitted from the enforcement of the strengthened legal frameworks by EOP

comment.narrative: At least 30

Target 100 achieved and surpassed
As noted above the number of systems all of which are relevant to this indicator stands at 163 as of midJuly

description.narrative: Volume of funding mobilized or granted from the incentives scheme by EOP US

comment.narrative:
Target 100 achieved
A financial rebate scheme has been developed with clear systems and processes The scheme has involved the pooling of GEF funds and Government funds into a single account at the Development Bank of Seychelles DBS A GEF contribution of US 633000 has been paid in and the Government has contributed SR 119 million approximately US 915000 for a total of US 1548000 to date

description.narrative: Enhanced national capacity for the development operation and financing of RET systems
No of entities in the country gainfully engaged in the various supply chain activities of the PV and RET markets by EOP

comment.narrative: At least 10

Target 100 achieved
A total of four PV supply and installation companies exist and at least one other is in the process of being researched and registered An additional 5 installers can be considered to be part of the national capacity All PV systems installed in Seychelles have been installed by local expertise which has been built as part of the project interventions

description.narrative: No of joint ventures andor licensing agreements between foreign PV manufacturers and local PV and RET companies facilitated by the business association by EOP

comment.narrative:
Target 100 achieved
Four companies Solar World Solar Watt Stiens and Yingli have official representatives in the Seychelles Relationships between local companies and foreign suppliers are healthy with all companies participating in supplier forums as well as training

description.narrative: No of local banksFIs that are providing financial assistance to gridconnected PV system projects by EOP

comment.narrative:
Target 100 achieved and surpassed
All five local banks are participating in the SEEREP as noted in the last reporting period This was achieved with the firm support and engagement of the Ministry of Finance Trade and the Blue Economy MFTBE the Seychelles Energy Commission SEC and the project The project is constantly monitoring and supporting the engagement of the local financial community with solar PV investments

description.narrative: No of personnel of the MOF local banks and FIs that are actively working on the formulation and implementation of incentive schemes and on the evaluation of the economicfinancial viability of gridconnected PV system projects by end Year 1

comment.narrative:
Target 100 achieved
More than 5 people are working to either assist with future iterations of the rebate scheme or FiT or SEEREP One local bank has taken the initiative of developing a department specifically targeting RETs and EE with several staff

description.narrative: Increased electricity production from RET systems eg PV systems and interest among energy sector investors and operators
Cumulative amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the project baseline from the demo projects by EOP tonnes CO2eq

comment.narrative:
Target 804 achieved
It is estimated that emissions reductions of 9772 tonnes CO2eq has been achieved as of 15 July 2015 This is based on a grid emission factor of 700 grams of CO2 per kWh being offset by PV The weighted time period has been considered in this calculation

description.narrative: Cumulative total electricity generation from gridconnected PV systems by EOP kWh

comment.narrative: Minimal

Target 822 achieved
Cumulative generation is at 1396029688 kWh as of 15th July 2015 This indicator is substantially the same as Indicator 3 above

description.narrative: No of replication projects implemented that are based on or influenced by the success of the PV system demonstrations by EOP

comment.narrative:
Target 66 achieved
Two projects are currently underway
1 UNDPGEF Resource Efficiency Project
2 Government Solar Homes Project
In addition the Government is in the process of designing a large project for potential GCF funding focusing on a zerocarbon footprint of La Digue and Praslin islands The approaches that will be adopted by this GCF project include widespread promotion and adoption of PV building upon the initiatives of the current GEF project

title.narrative: Management of Outer Island Protected Areas in Seychelles

description.narrative: Expansion and Strengthening of the Protected Area Subsystem of the Outer Islands of Seychelles and its Integration into the broader land and seascape

title.narrative: Project Document for Outer Island Project
Mid Term Evaluation of Expansion and Strengthening of the Protected Area Subsystem of the Outer Islands of Seychelles and its Integration into the broader land and seascape Project
Management of Outer Island Protected Areas in Seychelles

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
The project seeks to promote the conservation and sustainable use of terrestrial and marine biodiversity in the Seychelles’ Outer Islands.
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

- METT scores for 5 PA sites will improve from an average of 46% to an average of 77% - 5 new Protected Areas encompassing 76,258 hectares of marine ecosystems and 1,237 hectares of terrestrial ecosystems - MEE, SFA, and NGO partners implementing activities within framework of Ecosystem-Wide Zoning and Master Strategy - Cost effective practices and protocols for native forest re-vegetation and biosecurity shared among all PA management institutions in the Outer Islands

comment.narrative: 79. Under the ‘business-as-usual’ scenario, only one actively managed protected area (Aldabra Special Reserve) will be functioning in the entire area of the Outer Islands of the Seychelles. Other islands, such as Desroches, Alphonse and D’Arros, will have conservation staff but these will be operating without the ability to enforce restrictions on resource use, and in most cases, with extremely limited funds, staff and equipment. Furthermore, because the vast majority of conservation resources and activities in the country are focused on the Inner Islands of Seychelles, where the bulk of the human population is concentrated , government programs for conservation and sustainable development in the Outer Islands will remain almost non-existent. Funding support from government and donors for other sites will largely consist of irregular ad hoc investments in a few, select islands. In this scenario, most resource and activities will remain focused on the management of the Aldabra Special Reserve. The majority of remaining terrestrial and marine ecosystems and species in the Outer Islands will remain vulnerable, and increasingly threatened as tourism, fisheries and oil and gas development all move forward in the region.

1. Assessment, Monitoring and Conservation of coral reefs, sea grass beds, mangroves, terrestrial fauna, sea turtles, fish, seabirds, 2. Current and potential climate change impacts on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning assessed and monitored 3. Establishment of 'citizen science' recreational diver observation monitoring programme, 4. Preparation of terrestrial and marine habitat maps 5. Marine habitat mapping monitoring programs on Aldabra 6. Hiring of staff for Farquhar and Poivre Protected Area 7. Resources enhanced to ensure ongoing maintenance and application of the DSS at MEE Data Management Section 8. ICS programs for ecosystem Restoration and invasive species management

1. Assessment, Monitoring and Conservation of coral reefs, sea grass beds, mangroves, terrestrial fauna, sea turtles, fish, seabirds under development Preparation of terrestrial and marine habitat maps initiated and draft being finalized Marine habitat mapping monitoring programs on Aldabra launched Hiring of staff for Farquhar started but not for Poivre Island as waiting for hotel to build conservation Centre on Poivre ICS programs for ecosystem Restoration and invasive species management launched

Completion of Midterm Review Report -Completion of METT and Financial Sustainability Scorecard for all 4 islands -Undertake monitoring visit to the Island -Preparation of terrestrial and marine habitat maps -Vegetation and Habitat maps prepared - Assessment, monitoring and conservation of coral reefs - Assessment, monitoring and conservation of mangroves

• The mangrove conservation management plan and monitoring protocols have been submitted but not approved by ICS scientific committee. ICS to work on a plan to amend the document to be more site specific. • Bleaching events being monitored by Conservation Officers • Consultant organised a two-day monitoring workshop on 11-12 October 2016, with participants from SIF, MCSS, GVI and private consultants to discuss on a monitoring strategy. • Consultant have submitted draft monitoring plan in November, awaiting Scientific committee for comments. Desroches: • Waiting for the Seagrass and Coral reefs consultancies to be completed in order to correctly map the marine habitats. • ICS to purchase new satellite image for MEECC to assist with mapping. • Meeting organised with Mr Justin Prosper, MEECC, ICS head office, ICS Alphonse, ICS Farquhar and PCU to work on a strategy for the mapping of the habitats. • ICS to agree on classification scheme for terrestrial habitat maps. The Living Oceans Foundation classification will be used for the Marine habitat maps. • Free Landsat 8 images have been downloaded for Alphonse group, Desroches, Poivre, and Farquhar group. • ICS to follow up with US External companies to prepare quotations for satellites images for Desroches and Farquhar as it was not possible to map the marine habitat with the free Landsat 8 images.

description.narrative: Promotion and up-scaling of climate-resilient, resource efficient technologies in a Tropical Island Context in Seychelles

title.narrative: Mid Term Evaluation of the project: Promotion and up-scaling of climate-resilient, resource efficient technologies in a Tropical Island Context (Resource Efficiency

description.narrative: Promotion and up-scaling of climate-resilient, resource efficient technologies in a Tropical Island Context
independent political entity
To significantly reduce the rate of electricity consumption and water usage in Seychelles among underserved communities in the residential sector

1 Amount of reduced CO2 emissions from the power sector compared to the project baseline direct emissions reductions
2 Cumulative total electricity saved MWh
3 Cumulative total water saved m3

comment.narrative:
1 139590 tonnes CO2eq
2 12296 MWh per year or 184447 MWh for appliance lifetimes
3 446250 m3 per year or 6693750 m3 for device lifetime 20060 tons of CO2eq over their lifetime

Progress towards targets is not measurable at this time
Activities during the current reporting period which did not actually start until late 2014 were focused on establishing an enabling environment for the project and in initiating in parallel activities that correspond to subcomponents of the annual work plan Attention was paid to the needs for defining policies and putting in place legislation needed and developing baselines against which achievement of project targets including carbon emissions reduction targets could potentially be measured
It was realised however that specific attention is needed to develop a methodology that systematically quantifies the cumulative energy savings and avoided CO2 emissions of the measures and activities that are being developed and thus provide a means of reporting against the objectivelevel targets Attention will be paid to this during the next reporting period

description.narrative: Comprehensive and strengthened policy and legal frameworks adopted to promote residential resource efficient appliances

4 Key baseline data collected and analysed eg of appliances and consumption patterns in households consumer willingness or ability to pay of household spending that goes to electricity etc
5 SEC Efficiency and Renewable Energy Unit operationalised with clear mandate work plan and trained staff
6 Governmentapproved Energy Efficiency Strategy EES and Implementation Plan EEIP
7 Fiscal tax incentives in place for imports and purchases of energy efficient equipment except solar water heaters and energy saving lighting
8 Restrictions ban or limits on imports of nonenergy efficient appliances
9 System for measuring energy and water savings from EE residential appliances operational

comment.narrative:
4 No detailed information on residential or SME energy use
5 EE RE unit proposed but not yet fully staffed or operationalised
6 None only energy bill in place
7 EE equipment except solar water heaters and energy saving lighting currently subject to Value Added Tax VAT
8 No restrictions in place for imports of nonEE appliances no MEPS
9 No system in place for monitoring SEEREP by PUC

4 Baseline report completed by end of year 1
5 EE RE unit fully operational by end of year 1
6 EES and EEIP approved by end of year 1 and published by end of year 2
7 Customs Act regulations amended to remove duties on EE equipment by middle of year 2
8 Governmentapproved minimum energy performance standards MEPS approved by end of year 1
9 Computerbased MRV system in place by end of year 1 at PUC

4 Target not met baseline studies have been 10 achieved at the end of year 1 Two baseline studies have been initiated one concerning water demand in the domestic sector and one concerning energy demand The water demand study is expected to be completed at the end of September 2015 the energy baseline will be completed in May 2016 Baseline reports will thus not be ready until the end of year 2
5 Target not met setup of the EERE unit 25 achieved at the end of year 1 The second draft plan for the setup of the RE EE Unit prepared by the project ITE was submitted to SEC in May 2015 The first staff of the unit Principal Officer joined SEC in June 2015 and will work with the project to fully establish the Unit by the end of 2015
6 First target not met but on track to achieve second target The recruitment process for a consultancy to draft a Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Strategy and Action Plan was not completed during year 1 The consultant was identified in May 2015 and will commence work shortly The work is delayed somewhat by a review of the energy policy by the project ITE as there was a need for the elaboration of an amendment to the policy dedicated to EE and with defined targets for EE both in terms of setting time limits for the initiation of national energy management programmes and for the application of specific energy targets when it is possible to define them ie whenever baseline information is available This policy amendment was submitted to SEC in April 2015 It will guide the implementation of the consultancy to develop the EE Strategy and Action Plan which is expected to be completed by late 2015
7 Target 10 met Opportunities have been identified for revision of the VAT Act to widen the range of products that should receive VAT exemption However the reformulation of the VAT and Customs Act needs to be preceded by development agreement and putting into place a technical validation procedure to validate the eligibility of products This technical validation procedure could be a complete Efficiency and Labeling Standards Programme but could also be started up as a simpler process that will grow in complexity in a progressive manner to allow for stakeholders to become progressively more familiar with the process and its objectives
8 Target not met preliminary work is underway but there is a serious risk that this target will also not be reached by the end of year 2 as the process is complicated An integrated framework to develop the MEPS and the compliance facilitation processes and procedures was initiated in MarchApril 2015 but paused subsequent to a study visit of project staff and partners to Mauritius to interact with counterparts there that raised the possibility of simply adopting the framework applied there This needs to be followed up but meanwhile the ITE has developed an improved technical validation procedure that could replace the existing one characterised as being limited and not very objective and which could be the departing point to develop a complete Efficiency and Labeling Standards Programme This alternative was submitted to the SEC in June 2015 and a decision on the way to proceed will be made shortly
9 Target 10 met A consultant was recruited to undertake a review of the SEEREP recommend revisions and provide an action plan to implement the recommendations The initial review was completed and a report submitted in June 2015 The Ministry of Finance which implements the scheme did not yet express its views on the report It is not known if SEEREP will continue or not
Note To measure the impact of the project energy and water savings there is the need to develop a tool that is more encompassing than just monitoring the SEEREP This had not been planned in year 1 and the activity to elaborate such a tool will start during year 2 The tool will be developed and maintained at the RE EE Unit at SEC

description.narrative:
Outcome 21 Enhanced national awareness of the benefits of resource efficient appliances and verified behaviour change across targets groups regarding reduced energy and water use
Outcome 22 Consumers of RSE appliances aware of goals and conditions of the financing schemes for RSE technologies and of purchase and financing options available through these programs

Outcome 21
10 Full implementation of the Seychelles Energy Education and Communication Strategy SEECS for residential sector
11 of consumers and retailers aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and technologies via sampling and surveys
12 No of sites in Seychelles where consumers retailers and other stakeholders can learn about and see demonstrations of functioning energy efficient appliances
13 of energy efficient household appliances and water savings devices for which labelling scheme linked to MEPS in place
14 Quantitative assessment and feasibility study of potential energy savings kWh of absorption cooling technologies in the Seychelles and recommendations for strategies for increasing their uptake in the country
Outcome 22
15 of residential households andor SMEs aware of goals conditions and products offered by the financing schemes for RE technologies

comment.narrative:
Outcome 21
10 SEECS approved but no largescale actions implemented to date for residential sector
11 TBD by baseline study conducted in year 1
12 0 sites with RSE appliances open to public
13 0 labels exist in Seychelles linked to MEPS
14 Absorption cooling technologies very infrequently used in the country exact TBC by baseline study
Outcome 22
15 TBD by baseline study conducted in year 1

Outcome 21
10 SEECS Action Plan including component on residential water use reductions approved and under implementation by end of year 1
11 At least 50 of target audience contacted within the sample group are aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and practices
12 5 sites 2 households and 3 public facilities established and open to public by end of year 3 of the project
13 Labels approved for at least 5 types of household appliances and 2 water saving devices by end of year 1
14 Assessment report on Absorption Cooling Technologies completed and disseminated to all relevant stakeholders by year 2 with targets specified for uptake potential
Outcome 22
15 At least 80 of consumersSMEs contacted within the sample group are aware of the different financing schemes or technology transfer platform offered for RSE technologies

Outcome 21
10 Target 10 met The SEECS is being reviewed through a consultancy initiated in early June 2015 This is expected to be finalised in September 2015 The revised SEECS will be for the period 20152018 encompass aspects of water efficiency and will provide an action plan for implementation
11 Target not met The baseline for this indicator is being defined as part of the contracted baseline studies to be reported in the next PIR A market survey was done in March 2015 encompassing 9 retail outlets to determine retailer awareness Consumer awareness is being assessed through a number of activities as follows
The energy baseline study in the residential sector which will encompass 1000 households 35 of the households in Seychelles stratified by income group and will include explanation about RE the benefits of adopting EE appliances and responsible use of energy
One trade fair was carried out in April 2015 in Mahé The trade fair congregated about 15 suppliers of resource efficient technologies and was open to the public During the trade fair 100 visitors were assessed concerning their knowledge of EE appliances
The consultancy to revise SEEREP included a survey where 80 consumers on Praslin and La Digue were asked about their knowledge of EE appliances
All this information will be used to define the baseline for this indicator
12 Target 10 achieved A demo project has been initiated in La Digue school with additional support from the SEC and the CCI La Digue is the primary focus of Government to pilot processes leading to a carbonneutral footprint The project has been designed and the work will start soon Another demo project is expected to be implemented at SIT 1 monitored solar water heater and 1 monitored rain water harvesting system under a consultancy already planned and agreed with SIT under Component 32 The other demonstration projects will be defined in the next reporting period
13 Little progress towards the target as yet The establishment of the EL Standards Programme is still at an embryonic stage
14 Little progress towards the target as yet During the next reporting period a proposal will be made to engage an international consultant to provide the required input
Outcome 22
15 Target not yet met Three surveys have been conducted so far to assess the level of knowledge of the public concerning the existence and objectives of SEEREP The surveys have reached 100 persons on Mahé 50 persons on Praslin and 30 persons on La Digue The information resulting from these surveys and the information resulting from the baseline studies and revision of SEEREP will be used to establish the baseline for this indicator which will be defined during the next reporting period

description.narrative:
Outcome 31 Platforms established for training of technicians in the installation operation and maintenance of residential resource efficient technologies
Outcome 32 Capacity of key stakeholders improved to monitor and enforce the Minimum Energy Performance Standards MEPS and new energy labelling scheme

Outcome 31
16 No of private sector importers dealers and retailers of household electrical appliances with access to market information on product sourcing pricing quality etc and maintenance of RSE technologies
17 Training platform established to train technicians on installation and maintenance of RSE technologies

18 No of officers responsible for inspections of imported goods capacitated to evaluate compliance with relevant MEPS and related national labelling scheme

comment.narrative:
Outcome 31

Outcome 32
18 0 trained officers

Outcome 31
16 At least 20 private sector partners have received training and support by end of project
17 By end of project Seychelles Institute of Technology SIT operating a certificate course for technicians in installation operation and maintenance of resource efficient technologies no of technicians to be enrolled in course TBD during year 1
Outcome 32
18 At least 10 trained officers by end of year 2 of the project

Outcome 31
16 Preliminary work towards the target initiated A market survey with well defined objectives was carried out in 9 shops of different retailersimporters based on Mahé The action included some knowledge transfer and therefore contributed towards achievement of this outcome A continuous and coherent training programme addressing importers retailers and sales persons will be planned and initiated during the next reporting period
17 Target 5 achieved An exercise to assess the appropriateness of the existing course curricula and the ability of SIT to deliver the foreseen training has been completed The TOR for the reformulation and development of the training courses has been completed and approved by SIT After initiation of the consultancy it will be possible to determine the number of technicians to be enrolled in the course
Contact with the University of Seychelles was made in order to establish a training platform for shortterm courses that would focus more on energy management maintenance management and other technical topics eg thermal simulation of buildings and planning of green buildings that require specific knowledge but do not require long periods of time to be delivered A first set of courses is proposed to be delivered in February 2016
Outcome 32
18 No progress towards the target has been made this reporting period The MEPS and the respective compliance evaluation procedures have not yet been established and training cannot be undertaken until these are in place

Outcome 41
19a No progress towards the target has been made this reporting period During the next few months a detailed TOR will be prepared for a consultant to develop the policy framework for the establishment and enactment of a facility to manage the Electrical and Electronic Equipment Residues
19b No progress towards the target Preliminary discussion has taken place the drafting of the MoU will be part of the consultancy mentioned under indicator 19a above
Outcome 42
20 Target less than 1 met The review of the SEEREP financing mechanism put into place preproject by MoFBE submitted an initial report in June The uptake of SEEREP is very low fewer than 20 successful applications However it is realised that the scheme was implemented without having important structuring and flanking measures in place
The consultant concluded that there are opportunities for improving the publicity operation and monitoring of SEEREP In particular the monitoring of the number of households receiving the support of SEEREP is not recorded in a computer database and thus figures may not be entirely accurate
The position of the MoFBE regarding the continuation or revamp of SEEREP is not yet known The consultancy underway to review SEEREP will also put forward alternative financial mechanisms to be developed to complement SEEREP
The consultant also proposed a new reduction in the target of SEEREP from 8500 to 5600 noting that the target of 8500 is the Governments target which has been transposed as a project target This has not yet been discussed by the SEC and partners
21 Target 100 met preproject 7 banks have signed the MoU and 4 banks have already approved at least one loan through SEEREP
22 No progress towards the target Watersaving devices are not currently within the scope of SEEREP If the MoFBE decides to continue with SEEREP the action plan to reformulate it will need to increase its overall scope to add these devices especially rain water harvesting systems
23 Target not measurable as yet The energy baseline study will provide information concerning the feasibility of this target

title.narrative: Ecosystem Based Adaptation to Climate Change in Seychell

description.narrative: The proposed project seeks to reduce the vulnerability of the Seychelles to climate change, focusing on two key issues—water scarcity and flooding.

title.narrative: Ecosystem Based Adaptation to Climate Change in Seychell

description.narrative: The overall goal of the project is to ensure that development in the Seychelles is sustainable, and resilient to anticipated climate change effects.
independent political entity
independent political entity

1. Ecosystem services and natural assets maintained or improved under climate change and variability-induced stress 2. August mean daily discharge on two rivers (Mare aux Couchons Baie Lazare) with increased base flows 3.January mean daily discharge on two rivers with decreased flood flows 4. Number of water users with more reliable water supply 5. Area of rehabilitated coastal ecosystems 7. Approved water management policy framework being implemented for watershed areas

comment.narrative: 1. Project watersheds and coastal areas are regularly subject to water shortages and flooding events 2 Mare aux Couchons August Avg Mean Daily Discharge: 261.1 L/S and Baie Lazare August Mean Daily Discharge: 33.4 L/S 3. Mare aux Couchons January Avg Mean Daily Discharge: 595.4 L/S and Baie Lazare January Mean Daily Discharge: 173.1 L/S 4. 10% of PUC water supply customers in project watersheds without fully reliable surface water supply 5. # of tidal sluice gates installed: 0 6. Little wave energy attenuation provided by reef (5% of the pre-1998 bleaching event reef size) 7. Total hectares of wetlands rehabilitated to provide flood attenuation services: 0 ha 8. Total km of rehabilitated beach berms providing a barrier for coastal floods: 0 km 9. Total hectares of mangroves, wetlands, fringing reef, beach berms and other ecosystems with increased resilience to climate change impacts: 0 10. No policy and financing framework 11. No institutional mechanisms 12. Little information available regarding functional connectivity, watershed integrity and water balance of watersheds 13. Incomplete and ad hoc specifications for ecosystem rehabilitation

1. Watershed Management of 4 sites to include wetland rehabilitation, control of invasives, vegetation remapping 2. An integrated shoreline plan to be implemented 3. Commence legal and regulatory framework for the successful management of watersheds 4. Capacity building in climate change adaptation measures

Shoreline plan study launched and ongoing. study by eCoast started in 2015 and requires a full year so as to make study the wave dynamics of North East point during both the North West monsoon and the South East Monsoon season. 2 Watershed Committees established at Baie Lazare and North East Point Preparation of Vegetation map initaited.

Mare aux Cochons Watershed Management i. Starting of Invasive species management programme and Wetland rehabilitation
Baie Lazare Water shed Management - Starting of Invasive species management programme, Wetland Rehabilitation and assessing the impact of conflicts on water resources. - Initiation of consultative meetings between stakeholders. . Start vegetation management and replanting on Praslin at Find Boffay

TRASS has finalized the rehabilitation plan. In regard to the works to produce the required planting to increase the stock, it was agreed that the nursery should be extended, and an area adjacent to the existing nursery has been identified for expansion. With the assistance of the SNPA, seedlings are also being produced externally with the aim of increasing production to meet the target.
• 3 forestry operators and 1 assistant worked on a pilot forest rehabilitation of secondary forest by thinning invasives at Baie lazare. They worked on an estimated 2.5 ha of forest. • For the wetland rehabilitation, clearing of the invasive weeds in the wetlands will start in the fourth quarter prior to building a new barrage. The hydrologist is working in collaboration with the Public Utilities Corporation to design barrages that will contain gabions for more effective weirs. The wetlands rehabilitation will start as soon as the new barrages are approved by the relevant Government Authorities (MEECC and Planning Authorities  The consultant undertaking the vegetation assessment of the Mare Aux Cochons catchment submitted a revised draft report for review. Part of the report focused on the ecology and sensitivity of priority sites. A map to show the legend on habitat types and natural areas has been annexed to the report
The concept of vegetated gabions was selected and the project proposed the designing of a gabion rock weir. The first design for Bougainville, Baie Lazare has been completed. The project will seek the approval of the Planning Authority and Ministry of Environment, including the consent of adjacent landowners prior to construction
One consultant from the EcoSol Company conducted further Beach profiling and the data will be incorporated into the modelling being developed by eCoast consultants. The management plan will be formulated in 2017 following the collation of the baseline data

title.narrative: Cap Bldg for the Implementation of MInamata Convention

description.narrative: Strengthen national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and build capacity towards implementation of future provisions

title.narrative: Strengthen national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and build capacity towards implementation of future provisions

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Strengthen national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and build capacity towards implementation of future provisions
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

Outcome 1 Indicator 1.1 Report on analysis of policy and regulatory reform needed for the implementation of the obligations of the Convention 1.2 Report identifying national needs and gaps to strengthen institutional capacity to implement the Convention
Outcome 2 Number of activities organised to reach target audience. Number of people/institutions sensitized on the human health and environmental effects of mercury
Outcome 3 Country capacity built to effectively undertake a level 2 mercury inventory as per UNEP Toolkit Number of persons trained on undertaking a mercury inventory Level 2 as per UNEP Toolkit
Outcome 4 Report with a detailed description of sources of mercury releases and emissions in the country with quantification/estimation of these releases/emissions prepared.
Outcome 5: A Mercury Initial Assessment (MIA) Report, with detailed proposals on how to address the pertinent gaps and barriers in implementing the Convention, modifications to be made to legislation and detailed costing in meeting the obligations of the Convention, is prepared and made available.

comment.narrative: Overall Baseline: Limited or no literature currently exists

- Establish the PMU - Recruitment of a National Expert on Regulatory and Policy Review - Recruitment of a Public Awareness Expert to develop a awareness raising plan - Implementation of the awareness raising plan (specifically targeting decision makers, the general public and the population groups who are at risk): includes support of specific events - National Capacity trainings conducted and facilitated by the ITA for both the National Project Team and key personnel - Recruitment of national experts on data collection - Methodology and work programme of the Mercury Inventory to be presented by the national expert team to the PSC for approval

PMU established Consultant recruited and Level 1 Assessment completed Public Awareness completed and leaflets produced and sisseminated. Awareness raising plan (specifically targeting decision makers, the general public and the population groups who are at risk): includes support of specific events undertaken in 2015 National Capacity trainings conducted and facilitated by the ITA for both the National Project Team and key personnel data collection initiated.
Preparation of MIA report and Level 2 Assessment
MIA report completed and Level 2 Assessment completed and Validated. Project completed and will be closed operationally in Jan 2017

title.narrative: Inception Workshop Report for PA Finance Project

description.narrative: To improve the financial sustainability and strategic cohesion of Seychelles protected area system, while also dealing with emerging threats and risks to biodiversity in a shifting national economic environment.
independent political entity

title.narrative: Global Climate Change Alliance Seychelles Programme

description.narrative: The overall objective of the programme is: “To ensure that the people, economy and environment of Seychelles are able to adapt to and develop resilience to climate change and its effects, thereby safeguarding the sustainable development of Seychelles”.
